status_message: Today‚Äôs Green Holiday tip: Save energy (and money) by using LED lightbulbs on a timer!

This holiday season, call, email, or video-chat with your family to cut back on waste, and reduce your impact on the planet!

This year for a Green Holiday gift, give an experience that will last a lifetime and not end up in a landfill! 

Instead of giving merchandise, give tickets to a play, movie or sporting event or a gift certificate for dinner, a sports club membership or a spa treatment! The less material you buy the smaller your holiday carbon footprint will be.

This season go on the hunt for the perfect vintage one-of-a-kind-gift for your loved ones! 

Reduce your carbon footprint and buy second-hand toys, books, skis, and clothes to recycle old products and give them a new home.
Wrapping gifts in reusable materials, like comics, old maps, or magazines is fun, and saves you money. You can also cut up old holiday cards to make gift tags or decorations to hang.

This holiday season, shop smart and sustainably!  

Tag a friend who is good about shopping with reusable cloth bags, who avoids buying over-packaged goods, or who has an eye for gifting reusable products!
link_name: This holiday season, shop smart and sustainably!

Last week, Philippe Chemouny, manager at Environment and Climate Change Canada, won an Ozone Award during the 29th Meeting of the Parties to the Montreal Protocol. He was one of Canada‚Äôs key negotiators in some of the most challenging Montreal Protocol negotiations over the past 20 years, including the 2016 Kigali Amendment to phase down HFCs. Learn more about Mr. Chemouny: http://ow.ly/iBBy30gQSW0

In case you missed it during last week‚Äôs Facebook Live from the 29th Meeting of the Parties to the Montreal Protocol, Canadian David Heurtel won an Ozone Award for the development of Quebec‚Äôs provincial regulations on halocarbons. The Ozone Awards recognize individuals, groups and organizations that have demonstrated extraordinary commitment and contribution to the progress and achievements of the Montreal Protocol in the past 10 years. Learn more about Mr. Heurtel: http://ow.ly/JPwe30gQRE7

Last week, Dr. Vitali Fioletov, a research scientist at Environment and Climate Change Canada, received an Ozone Award during the 29th Meeting of the Parties to the Montreal Protocol. status_message: In case you missed it, Canada‚Äôs delegation worked hard at COP23 in Bonn, Germany, working to create a sustainable planet for future generations. We are all in on #ClimateAction!

Thanks to the Montreal Protocol, 99% of ozone depleting substances are eliminated in Canada and the hole is repairing itself. But, the work is not done!  Canada is committed to a full recovery of the ozone layer and action on climate change.
Join us now LIVE to watch a panel discussion on the science behind repairing the ozone layer and combatting climate change under the Montreal Protocol.

Tune in later today at 2:30PM EST for a panel discussion on the science behind repairing the ozone layer and combatting climate change under the Montreal Protocol.
 
Scientists from around the world, including Environment and Climate Change Canada scientists Vitali Fioletov and Nathan Gillet will be part of this panel.

The Montreal Protocol is one of the most successful global agreements ever. Together with the world, Canada stopped the thinning of the ozone layer. And now, 30 years later we are coming together under this agreement to stop climate change with the Kigali Amendment.
link_name: The Government of Canada is taking action

status_message:
Canada‚Äôs Minister of Environment and Climate Change, Catherine McKenna, is hosting an international meeting this week in Montreal focused, in part, on implementing one of the biggest, single, global climate actions ever taken: phasing down hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs). 

We all use HFCs in things like our fridges and air conditioners and they do a great job of cooling us down. Unfortunately, they also warm the planet. Delegates at the Montreal Protocol meeting are working to implement the Kigali Amendment to the Montreal Protocol which calls for a global HFC phase down. Countries adopted the Amendment last year and Canada recently became one of the first countries to ratify it. 

Canada is taking huge steps towards a clean future for our children and grandchildren, and as part of this, urges other countries to ratify the Kigali Amendment.

During the first meeting of the new #PoweringPastCoal Alliance, Canada‚Äôs Minister of Environment and Climate Change, Catherine McKenna, and the United Kingdom‚Äôs Minister of State for Climate Change and Industry, Claire Perry, were joined by partners unified in action to accelerate the clean growth economy through the rapid phase-out of traditional coal-fired electricity. 
 
#PoweringPastCoal partners agree that phasing out traditional coal-fired electricity is one of the most important steps the international community can take to meet the objectives of the Paris Agreement.

Indigenous peoples from Canada, and around the world, are disproportionately affected by the impacts of climate change. At the same time, their knowledge, experiences and innovations are vital when it comes to responding to climate impacts.

This is why Canada has worked so hard to ensure that the voices of Indigenous peoples are heard ‚Äî at home and abroad.
Today is Resilience Day at COP23. We are updating Canadian building codes and developing a retrofit code to adapt to climate change. Our goal is to create new clean buildings of the 21st century.

Congratulations to Dr. Bell and the team from Memorial University of Newfoundland who created SmartICE. 

At the United Nations Climate Conference COP23, they received the 2017 UN Climate Solutions Awards for their outstanding work adapting to climate change. They developed a tool that helps Indigenous Peoples adapt to thinning sea-ice. The tool provides information to aid in the planning of safe routes on the ice, which helps to reduce travel risks. 

SmartICE‚Äôs work underlines how global climate action is accelerating two years after the Paris Agreement was universally adopted. http://ow.ly/5J5C30gAhJl

Today is Finance Day at COP23. Clean technology innovation is a core component of the Government of Canada‚Äôs Innovation and Skills Plan.

In its most recent federal budget, the Government of Canada has pledged more than $2.3 billion to support clean tech growth across the country! Finance is a crucial aspect of growing green business.http://ow.ly/JqYw30gxphC

Today is Health Day at COP23. The Government of Canada is committed to reducing short-lived climate pollutants that are warming the planet and impacting our health, the quality of the air we breathe and the environment.

By using clean technology to reduce short-lived climate pollutants, we will grow the economy and meet our climate change and air quality goals. Cleaner air leads to improved human health, including fewer asthma symptoms, a reduced risk of premature death and fewer heart related issues. http://ow.ly/oIci30gwIds

The fight against climate change is just as important at the local-level as it is on the international-level. At COP23, we celebrate local initiatives like the Halifax Solar City Program. Check it out! http://ow.ly/gdAy30gwHMO

Today is Industry Day at COP23. It reminds us that transitioning to cleaner sources of energy is not only good for the environment,but good for our economy too. 

More and more, renewable sources of energy are becoming cost competitive with traditional sources. We know there are over $20 trillion in new opportunities for investments in emerging markets between now and 2030.

Canadian businesses are well-positioned to seize the opportunities that clean growth presents; resulting in new jobs, new technologies and less pollution. The Government of Canada is investing strategically to support growth across all sectors of the economy.

Today is Forests Day at COP 23. Did you know forests absorb and store carbon? These ‚Äúcarbon sinks‚Äù actually remove carbon from the atmosphere. 

Under the Pan-Canadian Framework, the Government of Canada will support efforts to enhance carbon stored in our forests, wetlands and agricultural soils. http://ow.ly/f5i530gwGYN 
https://www.canada.ca/en/services/environment/weather/climatechange/climate-action/federal-actions-clean-growth-economy/forestry-agriculture-waste.html
Today is Transport Day at COP23. Here at home, Canada is committed to investing in active transportation projects which will keep our communities healthy and clean. http://ow.ly/Kr0M30gw8Qa

Today is Oceans and Coastal Zones Day at COP23.

The Government of Canada recognizes the enormous potential for business development and job creation in the global marine renewable energy market which is projected at $900 billion by 2050.

Today is Human Settlements [AKA Cities] Day at COP23.

In Canada, about 12% of national greenhouse gas emissions come from heating and cooling homes and buildings. If we want to leave a cleaner planet, cities must adapt to deal with climate change. To address this issue, Canada is investing in climate-resilient infrastructure and standards.
